section.title: Dividing Exponents

introduction.p: Hopefully, you feel relatively comfortable with the ideas presented last lesson. We will continue on this idea by disassembling exponents and exploring properties of these exponents.

solution.p: We can write x^5 as x \times x \times x \times x \times x and x^3 as x \times x \times x. We can thus write \frac{x^5}{x^3} as \frac{x \times x \times x \times x \times x}{x \times x \times x}.

section.p: We can use this same logic to divide variables (and exponents).

solution.p:
We can write out x^4 as x \cdot x \cdot x \cdot x and x^2 \text{ as } x \times x. Now we can write out a fraction: \frac{x \times x \times x \times x}{x \times x} \frac{{\color{red}x \times x} \times x \times x}{\color{red}x \times x}
We know that \frac{x}{x} is 1, and so \frac{x \times x}{x \times x} can also be written as 1. Note that we can turn \frac{x \times x}{x \times x} into \frac{x}{x} \times \frac{x}{x}, just as we can write \frac{1}{2} \times \frac{3}{4} as \frac{1 \times 3}{2 \times 4}, and vice versa.
So, we can do the same thing to \frac{{\color{red}x} \times {\color{blue}x} \times x \times x}{{\color{red}x} \times {\color{blue}x}}. \frac{x}{x} \times \frac{x}{x} \times x \times x
Thus, we get 1 \times 1 \times x \times x, or just x^2.

section.p: Let's try another example. Now that we have a general idea, we can try creating a rule.
We have a broad rule now. Let's test it by putting it into action!

solution.p: We need to do this both ways. Let's do this the "new" way first. Our exponents are 3 and 2. We can just subtract 2 from 3: 3 - 2 = 1. So, our answer should be x^1 or just x.
Now let's do it the long way. x^3 is x \times x \times x, and x^2 is x \times x.
As expected, we get x. We can now form a generalization statement.

observation.p: We can write \frac{x^m}{x^n} as x^{m - n}.
